facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 178 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 178 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 19, 1963, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 388 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 19, 1963, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 388 of 1963.

facts.text: Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 1, was married to the complainant Indubai in about 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 1, was married to the companyplainant Indubai in about 1956.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 married Kamlabai in February 1962, during the lifetime of Indubai.

anchor.surface_text: He married Kamlabai in February 1962, during the lifetime of Indubai.

facts.text: Deorao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 2, is the brother of appellant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Deorao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 2, is the brother of the first appellant.

facts.text: Appellants No. 1 and No. 2, together with Kamlabai, her father and accused No. 5 (a barber), were tried for an offence under Section 494 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: These two appellants, together with Kamlabai and her father and accused No. 5, a barber, were tried for an offence under S. 494 I.P.C.

facts.text: Kamlabai, her father, and accused No. 5 were acquitted by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The latter three were acquitted by the Magistrate.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 was convicted under Section 494 IPC by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 1 was companyvicted under S. 494 I.P.C.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 was convicted under Section 494 read with Section 114 IPC by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: and appellant No. 2 for an offence under S. 494 read with S. 114 I.P.C.

facts.text: Appeal to the Sessions Judge was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Their appeal to the Sessions Judge was dismissed.

facts.text: Revision to the High Court failed.

anchor.surface_text: Their revision to the High Court also failed.

facts.text: Appellants contended that the prosecution needed to establish the second marriage was duly performed in accordance with religious rites.

anchor.surface_text: The only companytention raised for the appellants is that in law it was necessary for the prosecution to establish that the alleged second marriage...

facts.text: State urged that the marriage proceedings were in accordance with gandharva form custom in the community.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State it is urged that the proceedings of that marriage were in accordance with the custom prevalent in the companymunity...

facts.text: Essential ceremonies of invocation before sacred fire and saptapadi were not performed at the marriage of appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that these two essential ceremonies were number performed when appellant number 1 married Kamlabai in February 1962.

facts.text: No evidence on record to establish that performance of essential ceremonies was abrogated by custom.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom...

facts.text: The marriage took place at 10 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The marriage took place at 10 p.m.

facts.text: Wooden sheets were brought, a carpet was spread, accused No. 1 sat on one sheet, accused No. 3 on the other nearby.

anchor.surface_text: Pat-wooden sheets-were brought. A carpet was spread. Accused number 1 then sat on the wooden sheet. On the other sheet accused number 3 sat.

facts.text: Accused No. 4 performed puja with a tambya pitcher, betel leaves and coconut.

anchor.surface_text: Accused number 4 then performed some Puja by bringing a Tambya- pitcher. Betel leaves and companyonut was kept on the Tambya.

facts.text: Two garlands were exchanged between accused No. 1 and accused No. 3.

anchor.surface_text: Two garlands were brought. Accused number 2 was having one-and accused number 4 having one in his hand. Accused number 4 gave...

facts.text: Accused No. 1 and No. 3 struck each other's forehead.

anchor.surface_text: Accused number. 1 and 3 then garlanded each other. Then they each struck each others forehead.

facts.text: No Brahmin priest was called and no Mangala Ashtakas were chanted at the marriage.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of marriage in question, numberBrahmin was called and Mangala Ashtakas were chanted.

facts.text: Prosecution failed to establish the marriage was performed according to customary rites under Section 7 of Hindu Marriage Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai...

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside convictions, and acquitted the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the companyviction of appellant number 1 under s. 494 I.P.C. and of appellant number 2 under s. 494 read with s. 114 I.P.C. cannot be sustained.

facts.text: Bail bonds of appellant No. 1 stand discharged.

anchor.surface_text: The bail bonds of appellant number 1 will stand discharged.

facts.text: The marriage between appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai was not solemnized as per Hindu Marriage Act Section 17.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai does number companye within the expression solemnized marriage...
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 19, 1963, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 388 of 1963.
These two appellants, together with Kamlabai and her father and accused No. 5, a barber, were tried for an offence under S. 494 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Section 494 I.P.C. reads Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of its taking place during the life of such husband or wife, shall be punished with imprisonment of either descrip- tion for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

concepts.interpretation: Requires the second marriage to be valid according to applicable law; if not valid, no offence as it is not a marriage in the eye of law and not void under the section

concepts.unlisted_description: Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of its taking place during the life of such husband or wife

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 of the Hindu Marriage Act provides that a marriage may be solemnized between any two Hindus if the conditions mentioned in that section are fulfilled and one of those conditions is that neither party has a spouse living at the time of the marriage.

concepts.interpretation: Condition for valid Hindu marriage: neither party has a spouse living

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the commencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living, and that the provisions of ss. 494 and 495 I.P.C. shall apply accordingly.

concepts.interpretation: Applies only to marriages solemnized after commencement of Act; if not solemnized with proper ceremonies, not void under this section and IPC 494/495 do not apply

anchor.surface_text: Clause a of s. 3 of the Act provides that the expressions custom and usage signify any rule which, having been continuously and uniformly observed for a long time, has obtained the force of law among Hindus in any local area, tribe, community, group or family.

issues.text: whether in law it was necessary for the prosecution to establish that the alleged second marriage of the appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai in 1962 had been duly performed in accordance with the religious rites applicable to the form of marriage gone through

anchor.surface_text: The only companytention raised for the appellants is that in law it was necessary for the prosecution to establish that the alleged second marriage of the appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai in 1962 had been duly performed in accordance with the religious rites applicable to the form of marriage gone through.

issues.text: whether the proceedings of that marriage were in accordance with the custom prevalent in the community of the appellant for gandharva form of marriage and that therefore the second marriage of appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai was a valid marriage

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State it is urged that the proceedings of that marriage were in accordance with the custom prevalent in the companymunity of the appellant for gandharva form of marriage and that therefore the second marriage of appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai was a valid marriage.

issues.text: whether it is necessary for the commission of the offence under S. 494 I.P.C. that the second marriage be a valid one

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged for the State that it is number necessary for the companymission of the offence under S. 494 P.C. that the second 8 39 marriage be a valid one and that a person going through any form of marriage during the life-time of the first wife would companymit the offence under s. 494 I.P.C.

issues.text: whether the marriage between appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the performance of the two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their community

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that these two essential ceremonies were number performed when appellant No. 1 married Kamlabai in February 1962. There is numberevidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their companymunity.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court held that 'marries' in IPC s.494 requires a valid marriage solemnized with proper ceremonies.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged for the appellants that the essential ceremonies for a valid marriage were not performed during the proceedings which took place when appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai married each other.

arguments.claim: The proceedings of the marriage were in accordance with the custom prevalent in the community for gandharva form of marriage and therefore the second marriage was valid.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the State it is urged that the proceedings of that marriage were in accordance with the custom prevalent in the community...

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence that custom abrogated essential ceremonies; witness statements insufficient to prove custom; custom requires continuous uniform observance per HMA s.3(a).

arguments.claim: It is not necessary for commission of offence under S.494 IPC that second marriage be valid; going through any form of marriage during lifetime of first wife commits offence even if later marriage void.

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged for the State that it is not necessary for the commission of the offence under S. 494 P.C. that the second marriage be a valid one...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ads Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of its taking place during the life of such

arguments.court_reasoning: Prima facie 'marries' means valid marriage; not solemnized per HMA s.17, so no offence under IPC s.494.

arguments.claim: Expression 'whoever marries' in IPC s.494 means valid marriage; if not valid, no marriage in eye of law and not void under the section.

anchor.surface_text: Section 494 I.P.C. reads Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void... Prima facie, the expression whoever marries must mean whoever marries-validly...

arguments.claim: HMA s.17 makes second marriage void only if solemnized after Act's commencement while spouse living; provisions of IPC ss.494/495 apply accordingly only then.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the commencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living...

arguments.claim: Solemnize means to celebrate marriage with proper ceremonies and in due form; essential for s.17 and IPC s.494 applicability.

anchor.surface_text: The word solemnize means, in connection with a marriage, to celebrate the marriage with proper ceremonies and in due form, according to the Shorter Oxford Dictionary.

arguments.claim: Essential ceremonies for valid Hindu marriage are invocation before sacred fire and saptapadi, requisite even for gandharva form unless modified by custom.

anchor.surface_text: It is mentioned in Mullas Hindu Law... The Gandharva marriage... essential marriage ceremonies are as much a requisite... There are two ceremonies essential... invocation before the sacred fire, and saptapadi...

arguments.claim: No evidence that performance of essential ceremonies abrogated by custom in community.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their community.

arguments.claim: Witness statements do not establish custom abrogating essential ceremonies or that performed rites suffice for valid gandharva marriage.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the prosecution led no evidence as to what the custom was... Such a statement does not mean... There ought to have been definite evidence...

arguments.claim: Custom and usage under HMA s.3(a) requires continuous and uniform observance for long time to have force of law.

anchor.surface_text: Clause a of s. 3 of the Act provides that the expressions custom and usage signify any rule which, having been continuously and uniformly observed for a long time...

arguments.claim: Prosecution failed to establish marriage performed in accordance with customary rites as required by HMA s.7.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Marriage not solemnized under HMA s.17; does not come within mischief of IPC s.494.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the marriage between appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai does not come within the expression solemnized marriage occurring in S. 17 of the Act and consequently does not come within the mischief of S. 494 P.C.

holdings.text: Prima facie, the expression whoever marries must mean whoever marries-validly or whoever marries and whose marriage is a valid one. If the marriage is not a valid one, according to the law applicable to the parties, no question of its being void by reason of its taking place during the life of the husband or wife of the person marrying arises.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie, the expression whoever marries must mean whoever marries-validly or whoever marries and whose marriage is a valid one. If the marriage is number a valid one, according to the law applicable to the parties, numberquestion of its being void by reason of its taking place during the life of the husband or wife of the person marrying arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'marries' in IPC s.494 requires a valid marriage; mere cohabitation or invalid ceremony does not constitute marriage in the eye of law.

holdings.text: Section 17 of the Hindu Marriage Act makes a second marriage void only if it is solemnized after the commencement of the Act while either party has a living spouse, and only then do IPC ss.494/495 apply.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the commencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living, and that the provisions of ss. 494 and 495 I.P.C. shall apply accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of HMA s.17 conditions precedent for voidness and applicability of IPC bigamy provisions.

holdings.text: The word 'solemnize' means to celebrate the marriage with proper ceremonies and in due form; thus, essential for HMA s.17 and IPC s.494.

anchor.surface_text: The word solemnize means, in connection with a marriage, to celebrate the marriage with proper ceremonies and in due form, according to the Shorter Oxford Dictionary. It follows, therefore, that unless the marriage is celebrated or performed with proper ceremonies and due form it cannot be said to be solemnized.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary definition applied to statutory term 'solemnized' in HMA s.17.

holdings.text: Essential ceremonies for validity of Hindu marriage, including Gandharva form, are invocation before the sacred fire and saptapadi, unless modified by custom.

anchor.surface_text: There are two ceremonies essential to the validity of a marriage, whether the marriage be in the Brahma form or the Asura form, namely- 1 invocation before the sacred fire, and 2 saptapadi, that is, the taking of seven steps by the bridegroom and the bride jointly before the sacred fire.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reliance on authoritative text (Mulla's Hindu Law) for essential rites applicable to all forms unless custom proven.

holdings.text: There is no evidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their community.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence on record to establish that the performance of these two essential ceremonies has been abrogated by the custom prevalent in their community.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of prosecution evidence and witness statements insufficient to prove custom under HMA s.3(a) requiring long, continuous, uniform observance.

holdings.text: The prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of proof of essential ceremonies or abrogating custom; rites performed inadequate per law.

holdings.text: The marriage between appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai does not come within the expression 'solemnized marriage' occurring in S. 17 of the Act and consequently does not come within the mischief of S. 494 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai does number come within the expression solemnized marriage occurring in S. 17 of the Act and consequently does not come within the mischief of S. 494 P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of HMA ss.7,17 to facts; invalid solemnization excludes IPC s.494 liability.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed, convictions set aside, appellants acquitted
directions: The bail bonds of appellant number 1 will stand discharged.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 limiting HMA s.17 to post-commencement solemnized marriages addresses issue i3 by clarifying conditions for voidness relevant to IPC s.494 validity requirement.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the commencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living, and that the provisions of ss. 494 and 495 I.P.C. shall apply accordingly.

Section 17 provides that any marriage between two Hindus solemnized after the commencement of the Act is void if at the date of such marriage either party had a husband or wife living, and that the provisions of ss. 494 and 495 I.P.C. shall apply accordingly.

The word solemnize means, in connection with a marriage, to celebrate the marriage with proper ceremonies and in due form, according to the Shorter Oxford Dictionary. It follows, therefore, that unless the marriage is celebrated or performed with proper ceremonies and due form it cannot be said to be solemnized.

There are two ceremonies essential to the validity of a marriage, whether the marriage be in the Brahma form or the Asura form, namely- 1 invocation before the sacred fire, and 2 saptapadi, that is, the taking of seven steps by the bridegroom and the bride jointly before the sacred fire.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act.

We are therefore of opinion that the prosecution has failed to establish that the marriage between appellant number 1 and Kamlabai in February 1962 was performed in accordance with the customary rites as required by s. 7 of the Act.
